Mr. Braniff, I deeply regret what transpired between us last week. If I could go back, I’d behave much differently. Please know that my estimation of your character hasn’t wavered a bit throughout this ordeal, and that today I hold you in the same respect I always have. To Mr. Simon's ears this sounds like the proper kowtowing But Braniff knows: Cole is saying go-fuck-yourself.  57.

And let me say that I know your job’s tough. I mean, resentments are bound to bubble up when you feel sometimes like a... a glorified servant. He says this affably, but it is giant FUCK YOU back to Co
As for Mr. Braniff’s automobile? Cole’s eyes briefly flit to “The Wall,” then back to Bran He’s made his decision.
Sir, I will pay you back for all the damage that’s been done. And Braniff knows what Cole means: I’m coming for you. An it kind of makes him smile. Hey-ho, let’s go.

head_text.subj: MUSIC KICKS IN, TRANSPORTING US TO --

text: Lines and lines of Chinese immigrants sewing this year’s fashions for three dollars-an-hour. Sweatshop, U.S.A.

The factory MANAGER, a diminutive Chinese man, plays look at the door. A PAIR OF HANDS massages an office safe’s di To the right: click-click-click. To the left: clack-clack clack. Then: click-clack-click. The hands belong to SLIDE LINDUS. Cole’s childhood friend
Open says me. The safe complies. The Manager pushes Slide aside to get inside the safe but first Slide plucks up a band of cash within. The Manager protests in Cantonese but...
Ah-ah-ah-ah. Don’t even think about paying me in merchandise. You ain’t got nothing my size.  58.
Slide rides down surrounded by Chinese seamstresses, a go foot-and-a-half taller than the bunch. He smiles at them.
Any you ladies a masseuse? (his cell RINGS; he reacts to the ID and picks up) Old King Cole, you merry old soul, why are you admitting you know me?
Slide enters the restaurant, approaches Cole in a booth n a window.
Promise you won’t laugh.

FROM A DISTANCE AWAY: Cole and Slide bestride the sidewal Cole doing the talking, Slide the listening. Then, about halfway down the block, Slide stops in his tracks and sta at Cole. We can’t hear what he says but we can imagine. C smiles and insists: no, he’s not fucking with him. A BLOCK AWAY AND WE’RE HIGH ABOVE THE STREET NOW as Cole Slide round a corner. Cole points up and Slide looks.

specifically the penthouse. Slide looks upon it the way s men look upon Everest, with ambition and abject terror. And thus begins a RECRUITMENT MONTAGE -- EXT. MCCARREN PARK --— BROOKLYN -- DAY -- BEGINNING WITH DEV’REAUX, who is walking along, sudden aware of a PRESENCE walking behind him. Flicking a glance backwards, he sees a GUY with A BASEBALL BAT. Heart pounding, he picks up speed, afraid to break out into a d run, but veering off the path to the left. The guy keeps walking. Then approaches HIS 10 YEAR OLD KI tousles his hair and hands him the bat, pulling out a SOFTBALL. Just a Dad and son, playing ball. Dev exhales. Then stiffens, sensing more presences. Turns to find COLE and SLIDE standing behind him.  59.
Don’t you get tired of jumping out of your skin like that? DEV’ REAUX What you doing here?
How much do you owe those guys? And don’t say “what guys,” I know when you've been sleeping, I know when you're awake.”
(sighs) Okay. I made a few... optimistic predictions.
--Dumb-ass bets-- Dev’reaux really doesn’t get it. Stares at Cole. DEV’ REAUX How come you not firing me?
ON THE WHEELS OF A BABY STROLLER rolling along... pushed Fitzhugh, spending an afternoon comparing pathetically ul low prices on hideous canned meat. Cole falls in alongsid him.
Fitz. What if there was a way in this lifetime to permanently avoid Spam?
(defensive) You know, there are some people who actually like Spam.
You’re not one of them. EXT. COLE’S BUILDING -- NIGHT Cole loads a misty-eyed Lester into a taxi.
Mr. Howard, I don’t know how to...  60.
Sh-sh. No need, Lester.

(as they shake) Thank you... Cole. Lester gets in; the cab goes. Cole looks up. Sprinkled around the block, waiting, are Charlie, Slide, Dev’reaux Fitzhugh. Cole gives the signal: coast’s clear, c’mon in. INT. COLE’S APARTMENT -- NIGHT Our five guys sit around a fold-out card table. Cole has just laid out, with Slide’s help, “the plan.” The others stunned into silence by the audacity of it. After a spell Charlie leans forward and speaks. Very, very slowly.

Yeah. Good, good thinking. Let’s just rob the penthouse apartment of the building we work in -- with the tenant still inside -- with FBI agents STATIONED OUTSIDE THE FRONT DOOR, WITH security cameras -- to steal twenty million that MIGHT be in there -- IN THE MIDDLE OF OUR
There’s no mistaking Charlie’s tone for enthusiasm.
It’s a little frisky, I admit.
Why don’t I just pull out a bomb on an airplane? Same odds of getting away!
What do you think, Fitz?
Can you come back to me?
You said it: if you’re gonna steal, steal big.
Listen, I am beyond comfortable with white collar crime... (MORE )
no matter how much you steal, if you do it with decimal points instead of a crowbar...? Worst case, you’re out in two.
How far out you got our asses hanging on this thing?
Your jobs are compartmentalized. In fact, technically you wouldn't be doing anything illegal.
(he doesn’t want to skirt the truth) Well -- aiding and abetting.
(exasperated, to Cole) You’ve lost your mind.
Look. Braniff’s gonna walk away clean on this thing with 20 million dollars unless we do something. The five of us. You see? We’re the cavalry.

Oh, yeah, cavalry! A concierge, a building manager, an elevator operator... and this one -- this guy I don’t know from Adam -- your childhood buddy who YOU trust because he’s been stealing since you were in your playpen--? It’s a moment of truth between Charlie and Cole. They hol each other’s stares.
Charlie... You know why I’m doing this, don’t you?
Yeah, yeah, ‘cause of Lester. The man is 74 years old, you're gonna throw your life away for a --
Cause if we don’t do this, we’re all gonna be Lester!  62.
(suddenly) I’m in!
... Work hard for fifty years, play by the rules, then wind up with nothing! A beat. We sense Charlie almost wavering. But...
I got a family.
Then take care of them. ‘Cause no one else will. Another beat. Cole pulls out all the stops.
Come on, Charlie. It’s the first time he’s ever called Charlie by his first name, and we see it hit, in Charlie’s eyes. But then.
Low, low blow my friend. He starts to leave the room, turns at the door.
Any other time? That would've meant a lot. He goes. A beat.
You want me to kill him?
Would you stop?! He’s not going to tell anybody. But Cole is nervous. Fitzhugh speaks up.
When I am faced with a decision I generally make lists of pros and cons...? (waves the paper he’s been writing on) And it seems that... (MORE )

I would rather do hard time as someone’s bitch than see my family living in a car. Slide turns to Cole and smiles -- they have their crew! EXT. COLE’S BUILDING -- ROOF -- DAY A cold day in February. There will be no TRAINING MONTAGE cause there’s nothing to train for. There’s only this: ou four guys -- Cole, Slide, Dev and Fitzhugh -- bundled up overcoats, freezing their asses off on Cole’s frozen roof
OK, day of the heist, we’ve got to be prepared for different potentialities. (as Fitzhugh opens his mouth) No, that’s not a word. Don’t care. (Dev raises his hand) Yeah, Dev?
Why are we outside? My balls are sno-cones.
Yeah, can’t we go in? I can’t think.

Exactly why we’re up here. We don’t know how cold that day’s going to be, could be raining, could be hailing frogs. We've gotta be able to think on our feet. Okay so let’s say it turns out to be diamonds in Braniff’s safe. No problem, we put ‘em in our pocket. But what if it’s a stack of cash the size of... Cole points to an old rotting refrigerator box on the roo
We could throw it down the garbage chute, pick it up downstairs.
Okay, but how do we control the trash room?  64.
(to Slide) You’re the professional, you tell us. Slide looks from man to man to man, amused: this is who h working with. Then, he crosses to the refrigerator box --
Here’s what we do. -- plucks it up, tears it in two and crams it in an empty trash can. He sets his Zippo to it. Dev and Fitz gather around to warm their hands.
We lucky enough to get in and outta that penthouse with his shit, gettin’ it out of the building's the fun part! The men stare at him. What?! Fun? Slide turns to Cole.
(to Cole) When you thinking we do this? Cole joins the fire, his confidence shaken just a tad.
A day where people are very, very distracted. BAGPIPES and DRUMS transport us weeks ahead, to --

-- THE SAINT PATRICK’S DAY PARADE. Running straight up 5t Avenue. The sidewalks teem with onlookers. It’s March 16th. The day of the heist. REVELERS -- beefy, Irish looking blowhards, are tussling the street. Three of them pick up a fourth and stuff him a garbage can, all of them howling with laughter. Looming high above the parade -- lest we forget how very, very tall it is -- is The Tower.
Lester is back on the job. He monitors the crazed crowds through the front window as Fitzhugh comes up beside him.  65.
Who is St. Patrick, anyway?

The Patron Saint of cirrhosis. (a hand on his shoulder) Good to have you back, Lester. INT. THE TOWER -- COLE’S OFFICE -- DAY - TIGHT ON Cole’s fingers drumming on his desk. He’s nervous. MISS HOLLINGSWORTH stands before him, bitching, her 100 YEAR O MOTHER, OLD MRS. HOLLINGSWORTH in a wheelchair beside her catatonic. (We saw Miss H. before, bitching to Cole in th early montage.)
.--but Mother has to get her pills at EXACTLY NOON. And if you’ve given Rosie the day off! Who’s going to--
Rosie’s had an emergency. I've arranged a substitute.
(grudgingly accepting) Hmpf . INT. THE TOWER -- FITZHUGH’S APARTMENT -- DAY Kids scream and frolic, herded into coats by Mrs. Fitzhug In the bedroom, Fitzhugh tries to steel his courage.
Honey! We’re going! Fitzhugh steps out. Hugs each kid deeply -- will he be behind bars next time he sees them? -- kisses his wife.
I love you.
(off his intensity) Yeesh. We're going away one night, what’s up with you? She searches his face.  66.
Nothing!
I’d think it was another woman but you can’t even take her to MacDonald's. They laugh grimly. He hugs her tight.
Does Grandma have ice cream?
(mortified) Yes. Because Grandma has a freezer. Fitzhugh watches them to the elevator and Mrs. Fitzhugh b him a kiss before she disappears. Fitz catches it, scared

Charlie organizes the front desk. As far as he knows, it’ just another day. Until he eyes Cole and Dev exit the bac halls together and his antennae go up. Maybe it’s the conspiratorial way Cole sends Dev off on an errand. As Cole passes by, they trade nods: in the weeks since Charlie bowed out, a chilly distance has grown between th INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- DAY Susan Braniff dresses in her massive walk-in closet with floor-to-ceiling shoe shelves as her husband sits atop th bed talking on his cell.

-- no, Marty, I won’t, I don’t care, that’s too long. Go back, no, listen to me, go back and offer five months and tell ‘em I’1l give up Myerson, Witt and Golding -- (aside, to Susan) -- could you ask Cunningham or whoever’s on sentry today to get lunch? I’m starved --
(weary of her stay-at-home husband's demands) -- yes, I'll ask Cunningham or whomever’s on sentry --  67.

-- and ask him to go ahead and order, will ya? I’m gonna be on with Marty a while longer -- (back on the phone) -- whatya mean they don’t care about Golding, he was up to his tits in this -- WE GO WITH SUSAN through the apartment as she plucks up h purse. She hesitates at an envelope with two theater tick peeking out, takes them too. She exits into the elevator anteroom where young AGENT CUNNINGHAM keeps sentry.
Ah, so it’s you today, Agent--
(hates this gig, hates her) Cunningham. I’ve only told you a dozen times, ma’am.
You people all blur in my mind. My husband wants his lunch now. She presses the elevator call-button and --
-- ‘PH’ lights up on a panel. Washington reports in his m
Headed up to the penthouse.

Cole hears this on his walkie/takes out his cell/dials. INT. MISS HOLLINGSWORTH’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS The stringy, Miss Hollingsworth gestures contemptuously a OLD MRS. HOLLINGSWORTH in a wheelchair -- Brooke Astor incarnate. In front of the aged lady is a tray with Jell- and on the tray, SEVERAL PILLS.
Now, she gets very agitated -- I need you to help me hold her while you give her the pills.  68. The CAMERA turns around. And we see that the ATTENDANT helping her... is DEV’REAUX.

Yes, yes... they explained it all to me, ma’am. At your service. As they approach the old lady, she moans and shrinks in terror. Dev can’t help but notice: DEV’REAUX (CONT’D) She really don’t like ‘em, does she?
It’s total dementia. She doesn’t know what’s best for her.

Yes, ma’am. As Miss Hollingsworth holds her mother, Dev’reaux RAISES PILLS to the woman’s lips... ...then PALMS THEM. Is that a flicker of appreciation in the old woman’s eyes We’re not sure. INT. THE TOWER -- FITZHUGH’S APARTMENT -- CONTINUOUS The place is nearly empty now. A sofa, a cabinet, little else left. Fitz sits, eyes closed, when RIINNG.
Yes, Mr. Howard? COLE’S VOICE Mr. Fitzhugh, you’re up.
Washington and Mrs. Braniff ride in silence. DING! Fitzhu steps aboard. Smiles are exchanged.
Hello. Sorry, we met around Christmas. I’m Chase Fitzhugh.
(an unpleasant memory) I remember.  69. The doors close.
(making conversation) off to lunch?
My friends tell me it’s unwise to be seen eating out these days. They mean it’s unwise for them to be seen eating out with me these days. Fitzhugh feigns empathy.
How awful! You did nothing wrong. (spots the theater tix) Ah, you have tickets for a matinee. What show?
These? Someone dropped them off yesterday, someone I obviously don’t know, because I despise Shakespeare.
(through clenched teeth) Just a mass of cliches, isn’t he? Nodding in agreement, she RIPS THE TICKETS IN HALF, tosse them. Fitzhugh sighs. Strike one. DING! They exit.
Cole withdraws a cake from a hiding place. Sets it alongs a cake knife, plastic forks, paper plates, etc.. Licks frosting off his hand --
Mr. Howard, you wanted to see me?
Yes, Ms. Dolowitz. Would you assemble the maid staff in the package room please?
(nervous ) Now?  70.
No job cuts. Don’t worry. (she moves to use her mic) Radio silence if you would. Ms. Dolowitz thinks it odd but obeys. As she goes, Dev arrives in the doorway. He nods: mission accomplished.
Charlie tracks Mrs. B and Fitz out the elevator door and across the lobby as Cole appears.
Mr. Gibbs, Mr. Svichkar, may I see you both in the package room?
(on guard, resistant) Who’1l watch the desk?
Mr. Dev’reaux can.
(fuck) Certainly. Dev comes around to man the front desk. Svichkar heads in the package room and Charlie follows him, reluctantly.
Susan Braniff exits the Tower, followed by Fitzhugh.
Thanks, Lester. (to Mrs. B) Beautiful day. You know what I love to do on days like today? Take the ferry to Staten Island. Out on the water, feel the breeze, drink a little chablis...
(a brushback) Then I think you should go do that. Good afternoon, Mr. Fetzer. She goes. Foiled, Fitz gives her a moment, then tails her  71.
Charlie joins Washington, Dolowitz, the maids and other s here. Cole signals them to enter quietly.
Cole, what are you --

Sh-sh-sh. (then, in a stern voice) Ms. Perez, a word with you. Perez’s had her nose in the mail until now; she looks up, surprised to find so many people in her workspace. COLE (CONT’D) Ms. Perez, your job here is to monitor the delivery of incoming and outgoing mail. And yet the most important letter this building may receive all year slipped your attention. (withdraws an envelope) From the “American Bar Association?” She swallows hard as he hands over the letter. Everyone i the room looks hopeful for her. She opens it, starts to read...and her eyes well up.
I passed! (everybody cheers) How did you know?! I might’ve flunked!

I know exactly how much time you had to study. Congrats, counselor. Cole reveals the cake from the kitchen. As Perez cuts the first slice, Cole glances at Charlie, who feels foolish f being so paranoid. However --
-- at the front desk, Dev has seized the moment to disman the front desk switchboard and detach Braniff’s phone lin
Mr. Dev’reaux, piece of cake?  72.
You betcha. As Dev’reaux reaches for his slice his hand brushes again Cole’s, and COLE PALMS SOMETHING out of Dev’s hand. One guess what.
Mrs. Braniff navigates a path through the St. Patty’s Day revelers. Not far behind Fitzhugh keeps an inconspicuous tail. She diverts onto a side street and he mirrors her.
A DELIVERY GUY from the neighborhood deli enters. He salu Charlie, back at his post --
Lunch for Rapunzel. -- and Charlie waves him on through. Just then Cole emerg with two slices of cake in hand.

Just a sec. Do me a favor and take these up to Mr. and Mrs. Braniff? We’re all pretty torn up that they’re unjustly imprisoned this way and can’t be part of our celebration, and they do love German chocolate cake... (the Delivery Guy glares at him: you kidding?) I know, “do it yourself,” but see, the FBI draws guns when there's extra people up there... Here, let me take these and you take these... And before the Delivery Guy can protest, Cole’s taken his delivery pouch from him and loaded him with two plates of cake, forks, napkins, etc. Charlie knows something is up.
Got ‘em? Great. Thanks.
(under his breath) Next time wait on the prick yourself.  73. Charlie’s antennae are up again. He turns to see: the ent Tower staff is eating cake. Uh-oh. He sets down his slice
A SQUADRON OF MOUNTED COPS pass by, on parade. INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- CONTINUOUS Braniff watches the parade from his window, on the phone.

No -- wait -- no -- THURSDAY? I want to be out of here MONDAY -- I’ve got a villa reserved in Como-- OK, OK, yeah. If you can get that, close it. Let’s make the deal and be done with it. (he hangs up; there’s a KNOCK at the door) Yeah?
(sticks his head in) Lunch is here.

head_text.subj: ON A PAIR OF FLORSHEIM WINGTIPS CLICKING ALONG THE SIDEWA

text: They belong to a man in a Brooks Brothers suit, bespectac carrying a briefcase. He approaches the Tower.
May I help you, sir?
(a mid-Atlantic accent) Yes, I’m here to see an apartment. INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- DAY The Delivery Guy places sandwiches on Braniff’s dining ta And the TWO SLICES OF CAKE.
(re: the cake) What’s this shit?
They gamme it downstairs, some guy. Braniff eyes the cake, uneasy.  74.
(suspicious) Not the manager?
Maybe.
Was he supercilious?

--Expi-alidocious! The delivery guy gives him a fuck-you grin. Braniff scowl pays the guy. And pointedly gives him a ONE CENT tip. Whe the delivery guy and Cunningham are gone, Braniff takes h food straight to the kitchen -- -- and dumps the cake in the trash. He’s not taking any chances if it was sent up by Cole. Then: he unwraps his corned beef sandwich and takes a bite.
Cole bites into an identical corned beef sandwich. Charli appears in his doorway.
Dijon?! How ivory tower, Dijon on corned beef...!
If that was Braniff’s, you sure they all obeyed your order about not spitting in it?
They always obey my... He thinks. Hm. He drops the sandwich in the trash.
Stop this. Now. So far the worst you've done is, what, drug the man?
That is a horrible accusation. He ain’t sayin’ a thing.
He can still just wake up, never know what happened. If you keep going with this...  75.
What, Charlie? You'll call the cops on me? After all the years we've worked side by side?

Don’t make me choose. We see, on his desk, PICTURES of Charlie with a WIFE and KIDS. Also children’s DRAWINGS -- Fathers Day Cards. Cole sees what Charlie has to lose. He nods. Over both their walkies: SVICHKAR’S VOICE Mr. Howard, I have a Mr. Bissell here to see you. Cole starts out. Charlie shoots him a look -- don’t! Cole measures him, goes anyway.
Korean manicurists start in on Mrs. Braniff’s hands and f she lies back, towel over her eyes, indulged to the max. Fitzhugh monitors from across the street, checks his watc
Slide, in costume, speaks to Svichkar at the front desk.
-- I spoke to Mr. Fitzhugh himself and he assured me it was fine.
We still have to follow protocol. (Cole arrives) Mr. Howard, this is Mr. Bissell. He was hoping to view the Fitzhugh property but they’re not at home.
Not a problem. I'’11 show you up. Emerging behind Cole, Charlie takes one look at Slide in pinstripe suit and can’t contain himself.
Oh, c'mon, you gotta be, you can’t expect anyone’ll believe this...  76.
Mr. Howard, we don’t have clearance from the Fitzhughs.
That’s okay, Mr. Svichkar. Come, Mr. Bissell, elevators’re this way. Charlie spots Mr. Simon entering the lobby and recognizes chance to safely sabotage Cole’s heist.
(too loudly) Are you forgetting that we need written consent from an owner before admitting any visitor into their unit? (Cole keeps moving) Isn’t that right, Mr. Simon?!
(finally paying notice) Is there a problem, Mr. Howard? Cole stops, shoots Charlie a look: well played. Then:
I have the situation under control, Mr. Simon.
What situation?
This gentleman is here to see the Fitzhugh apartment. Unfortunately we have no written consent from them.
Then there’s no issue. He can’t go up. Advantage: Charlie. Cole’s stymied. He’s rescued by --
Perhaps I can shed some light, Mister...?
Simon, Tower property manager.  77.
Morris Bissell, Liberty Mutual. My bank handles the Fitzhugh mortgage.
Don’t you mean “handled?” He snickers at his own (unfunny) joke. Slide draws Mr. Si aside, for discretion’s sake. Meanwhile, Mr. Lindus approaches/distracts Charlie.
...why are all these people outside?...
Recently we were forced to foreclose on the Fitzhughs, sadly. We allowed them a thirty-day grace period to move but technically the bank is now tenant of record so...
Sorry, your name again was...?
Morris Bissell. He withdraws a business card, hands it to Simon. It reads “Morris Bissell, Liberty Mutual.” Simon turns to Cole:
Take him on up. Sorry for the confusion, Mr. Bissell. Now it’s Charlie who’s stymied. As Cole and Slide continu to the elevators, under their breaths:
Where’d you get the business card?

Some dude’s wallet I... found. Your buddy gonna be cool? Cole shoots Charlie a look as he boards the elevator and Slide sets a finger to his lips just as its doors close. Charlie, incensed, grabs the phone at the front desk. He starts to dial, then hesitates.
Who you calling?  78.
I don’t know. (he slams the phone down; Cole was right; he can’t turn them in) Shit! MUSIC PUMPS UP as the heist kicks into higher gear and --

head_text.subj: -- COLE AND SLIDE EMERGE FROM A DOORWAY AND STEP OUT INTO
THREE-SIXTY VIEW OF THE CITY SURROUNDING THEM.

text: Dev’reaux is already here, supplies in hand. He tosses ea man a white jumpsuit and gloves, then proceeds to remove tarp from a WINDOW-WASHING PLATFORM stored at the roof ed MOMENTS LATER, Cole and Slide, wearing their jumpsuits ov their suits, help Dev hoist the platform over the side of building and into position. Slide peers over the side: it’s a heart-stopping, vertigi view. Cole appears beside him.
You ever done this before?
I get dizzy stepping off the curb. (cell buzzes; he picks up) Mr. Fitzhugh, how are we?
Fitzhugh continues to watch Susan Braniff’s nails get don
They’ve finished moisturizing her feet and’re about to start buffing.
Do you have a plan?
I’m... pondering. From a newsstand he plucks up a magazine promoting an art “Inside The Braniff Swindle.”
Cole hangs up, dials a new number. Meanwhile, Slide tests the platform cables’ strength. To Dev:  79.
How much weight can this baby bear? Dev has only his elevator operator experience to guide hi
I push the buttons! Do I look like a structural engineer! INT. THE TOWER -- BRANIFF’S PENTHOUSE -- DAY Braniff’s cell RINGS on his dining table. Braniff is nowh to be seen. Is he asleep?
Cole hangs up.
No answer. Whatya think?

We got two hours. Tops. As good a final thought as any. Over the side they go. A WIDE VIEW of the Tower, Central Park beyond it, the par on the street below and on top our two faux window-washer climbing out onto a two-foot wide, ten-foot long apparatu Dev hands Slide his banker’s briefcase as he gives Cole a quick tutorial.
This is your ‘up’ button, this is your ‘down.’ This locks it in place. Run into any trouble, this might be manual override I got up here. Might not.
You got my back. Nice to know. Cole lowers them from view.
Fitzhugh enters, approaches the young female PROPRIETOR a the front, careful not to be seen by Mrs. Braniff within.
Hi... Speak English? (she indicates a little; he opens his magazine) Know who this is? (MORE )

(he points out Braniff; (she nods/scowls) Good. This is his wife. He points from a picture of Mrs. Braniff to the real deal currently being waited on by a trio of manicurists. The Proprietor doesn’t like this one bit.
(her English is better than she let on) That bitch is in my shop? Fitz takes out a pair of $100’s.
Need you to do me a favor.

ABOARD THE PLATFORM WITH COLE AND SLIDE, more than anythi else it’s claustrophobic up here: there’s no place to go, barely any place to step. Both Cole and Slide can’t help looking at the drop as they descend.
Aren’t we not supposed to look down?
I remember that now. --My God!! (re: a streaked window pane) I’ve been paying these window washers, and THIS is the service they-- these people are criminals!!
You the criminal!!
(nonplussed) No! I’m...

You just “frisky.” FROM WITHIN THE PENTHOUSE: The window-washer apparatus lo into view. Still no sign of Braniff inside. Cole stops their descent when they’re flush with the apartment. OUTSIDE: Slide opens up his briefcase. Inside is the very latest in fiberglass-cutting technology: a suction-clamp an extendable arm attached to a blade.  81. Slide affixes it to the window and prepares to cut. He lo to Cole, who dials Braniff’s cell again. INSIDE: Braniff’s cell RINGS. Unanswered. OUTSIDE: Cole nods to Slide: do it. Slide begins to cut. INSIDE: While it’s not exactly noisy, the bladework’s lou enough to draw attention from anyone inside the apartment ON THE ROOF, Dev watches from above. Over his walkie: WASHINGTON’S VOICE Mr. Dev’reaux, what’s your twenty? DEV’ REAUX I’m, um, in the building -- why? WASHINGTON’S VOICE Mr. Svichkar’s taking his break, need you to come cover for him.

Why, certainly. On my way. He mouths: FU-UCK! He doesn’t move. A FLOOR BELOW: Slide finishes slicing a four-foot circle of the window. Then, with a practiced push, he thrusts th entire piece of fiberglass into the penthouse without dropping it, then lays it softly on the floor.

Now this I’ve done. A pro at this, Slide lifts one leg out of the apparatus, straddling its rail, then dips his foot inside the four-f hole. When his foot’s flat on the floor, he pulls himself over and inside the apartment, ducking his head as he goe Now it’s Cole’s turn. Not a pro. He tries to mimic Slide’ method but once he’s got a foot inside the penthouse -- -- a sharp wind picks up and banks off the edifice, pushi the apparatus out. Just as Cole begins to flounder, Slide reaches out and grabs him and pulls him in. They’ve breached the penthouse. INT.
